ncy response training is part of the plan and the most recent training is referenced in the Risk Management Plan. The facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the East Liverpool Fire Department. The plan is updated whenever there are changes at the facility that may impact emergency response actions. In addition, extensive training is performed for onsite emergency response and maintenance of the onsite fire brigade. Copies of the plan are made available to the county LEPC and city fire department.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
HTS believes that the processes at the facility are operated and maintained in a safe manner. Improving safety is continuously ongoing at the facility and our highest priority. HTS plans to take all necessary, realistic, technical and economically feasible actions to improve safety whenever determined to be necessary.

than a mile and a half from the Pennsylvania-Ohio border. The closest incorporated areas to the facility include East Liverpool, Ohio; Chester, WV; Wellsville, Ohio; and Midland, Pa. The area in the immediate vicinity is mixed residential and commercial with some light industrial activity present and a gently rolling urban topography. The facility is situated on a 21.5 acre tract. The site is bordered on the north by Norfolk Southern railroad tracks, on the east by Growmark, on the south by the Ohio River, and on the east by Heritage Transportation. The area immediately surrounding these properties is zoned medium-high density residential use.

Wastes are received at the facility in liquid, solid, and semi-solid form in packages (lined boxes, fiber packs, metal cans, drums, reusable containers, etc.) or in bulk roll-off boxes, tankers, etc.). The wastes are pre-approved and registered in a computerized tracking system. Upon arrival, the wastes are weighed and the associated paperwork reviewed to verify compliance with regulatory requirements. The wastes are sampled and, after approval, directed to the appropriate process treatment area. Bulk liquid wastes are unloaded under a roof in a contained, concrete area. The tankers are purged with nitrogen. Fugitive emissions are captured and vented to the incinerator or treated through activated carbon units. Limited types of bulk liquid wastes are pumped directly to the kiln from the tankers. Drummed wastes are processed under a roof in the drum processing building. Organic waste blending occurs in an indoor tank farm.

All waste handling, storage, and treatment areas are in concrete containment and utilize collection sumps to capture any spilled materials. 

Regulated Substances Handled
All chemicals at the facility are received from waste generators around the nation. The facility receives wastes from various generators and the constituents of the wastes vary. Consequently, HTS has indicated in the RMP that it i

ncludes predictive filing. However, only wastes conforming to pre-selected profiles are accepted at the facility. The waste profiles include constituents and ranges of percentage of the constituents. Based on a comprehensive review of waste profiles received at the facility, the following list of regulated substances could be reasonably expected to be present at the facility at any given time above the threshold quantity (TQ) established pursuant to the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68):

1,1-Dimethylhydrazine, Acetaldehyde, Acrolein, Acrylonitrile, Acrylyl chloride, Allyl alcohol, Allylamine, Ammonia (conc. 20% or greater), Chloroform, Chloromethyl methyl ether, Crotonaldehyde, Crotonaldehyde (E)-, Cyanogen chloride, Cyclohexylamine, Dimethyldichlorosilane, Epichlorohydrin, Ethyl mercaptan, Ethylamine, Ethylenediamine, Ethyleneimine, Formaldehyde (solution), Furan, Hydrazine, Hydrochloric acid (conc. 37% or greater), Iron, pentacarbonyl-, Isopropyl chloroformate, Isopropylamine, Methacrylonitrile, Methyl chloroformate, Methyl formate, Methyl hydrazine, Methylamine, Methyltrichlorosilane, Nickel carbonyl, Nitric acid (conc. 80% or greater), Oleum, Pentane, Peracetic acid, Phosphorus oxychloride, Phosphorus trichloride, Piperidine, Propionitrile, Propyl chloroformate, Sulfur trioxide, Titanium tetrachloride, Toluene 2,4-diisocyanate, Toluene 2,6-diisocyanate, Toluene diisocyanate (unspecified isomer), Trichlorosilane, Trimethylchlorosilane, Vinyl acetate monomer, and Vinylidene chloride.

The regulated substances are present in six processes, which are currently in operation at the facility: 1) the organic waste tank farm; 2) the drum storage - canopy; 3) the container processing/receiving and pump-out/blend tanks; 4) the drum storage - truck wash; 5) the direct tanker unloading, and 6) truck hold and sample.

Accident Release Prevention Program
The HTS facility has developed and implemented a PSM program for the processes covered by the RMP. HTS

performs daily, monthly, and annual inspections of all process components. Safe operating procedures are regularly reviewed and updated whenever necessary. The operators are regularly trained on handling wastes in the various process areas and on emergency response actions. Deluge systems are installed at all possible areas of release to contain fires. In addition, any release within the buildings is vented to the incinerator or activated carbon system, which operates continuously. Fire suppression systems are installed in all process areas and direct communication is maintained through an automated alarm system at the facility and monitored by the local fire department.

In November 1998, HTS became the first commercial hazardous waste incineration facility to obtain certification to the ISO 14001 standard, the international standard for environmental management. To complement this certification, HTS also obtained certification in the 1S0 9001 Standard, the international standard for quality management. As part of the process, HTS has critically reviewed safety and health issues at the facility. The ISO certification demonstrates HTS's commitment to the employees and the community by maintaining safety, the environment, and quality in our operations and in customer service. HTS has further strengthened this commitment by achieving OHSAS 18001 certification in August of 2009. OHSAS 18001 is an international occupational health and safety management system specification.

Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases from any of the covered processes at the facility in the last five years, which meet the reporting criteria of the RMP. HTS is committed to maintaining this safety record.

Emergency Response Program
The emergency plan includes emergency and incident notification, reporting, emergency health care, emergency response actions, training and drills, and an incident prevention program, which fulfills all requirements of RMP. Emerge

Executive Summary

Environmental and Safety Policy:
It is the policy of Heritage Thermal Services, Inc. (HTS) to conduct itself as a good corporate citizen, to be a responsible member of the region's industrial community, and to comply with all federal, state, and local environmental laws and regulations. HTS strives continuously to maintain safe operations and implements safe operating procedures in all processes at the facility.

HTS practices a proactive approach with respect to communications with East Liverpool and neighboring communities. The facility's Web Site (https://www.heritage-enviro.com/heritage-thermal-services/) provides information on safety, environment, training, plant improvements, tours, and other pertinent information. In 2015, HTS initiated a formal process to meet with community leaders and interested citizens to discuss company activities and topics of mutual interest.  Members of the Community Advisory Panel (CAP) represent local business, government, emergency response, education, civic organization and industry.  The HTS team updates CAP members about recent activities at the facility, including safety and environmental performance, business developments and other community outreach activities.

In short, HTS maintains safe operations at the facility and practices open communication with the local community, many of whom are employees of the facility.

Stationary Source
HTS operates a hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility (TSDF) in East Liverpool, Ohio. Solid and liquid wastes within permit specifications are received in the facility and thermally treated in a rotary kiln incinerator. The facility has a final permit status under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (RCRA).
